verses.text: After the death of Saul, when David had returned from defeating the Amalekites and had remained two days in Ziklag,
verses.comment: David is still in Ziklag, recovering from the battle with the Amalekites and the death of Saul.

verses.text: on the third day, a man came from Saul’s camp, his clothes torn and dirt on his head. When he came to David, he fell to the ground and paid him respect.
verses.comment: Torn clothes and dust on the head are traditional signs of mourning.

verses.text: David said to him, 'Where do you come from?' He said to him, 'I have escaped from the camp of Israel.'
verses.comment: The man is an Amalekite, but he first identifies only as an escapee from Israel.

verses.text: David said to him, 'How did the matter go? Tell me.' He answered, 'The people have fled from the battle, many of the people have fallen and are dead, and Saul and his son Jonathan are dead also.'
verses.comment: The report confirms the death of Israel’s king and prince.

verses.text: David said to the young man who told him, 'How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?'
verses.comment: David seeks to verify the news with direct evidence.

verses.text: The young man who told him said, 'I happened by chance to be on Mount Gilboa. There was Saul, leaning on his spear, and the chariots and horsemen had overtaken him.'
verses.comment: The man's account is somewhat different from 1 Sam. 31, where Saul falls on his own sword.

verses.text: 'When he looked behind him, he saw me and called to me. I answered, “Here I am.”'
verses.comment: The man claims a conversation with the dying Saul.

verses.text: 'He said to me, “Who are you?” I answered him, “I am an Amalekite.”'
verses.comment: An Amalekite was an enemy of Israel, adding irony to the narrative.

verses.text: 'He said to me, “Stand over me and kill me, for agony has seized me, but I am still alive.”'
verses.comment: The account gives Saul’s own command for his death, differing from the historical report.

verses.text: 'So I stood over him and killed him, because I was sure that he could not live after he had fallen. I took the crown that was on his head and the bracelet that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.'
verses.comment: The man may be lying to gain favor with David, as 1 Sam. 31 says Saul killed himself.

verses.text: Then David took hold of his clothes and tore them, and so did all the men who were with him.
verses.comment: Tearing clothes is a sign of grief.

verses.text: They mourned and wept and fasted until evening for Saul and for Jonathan his son and for the people of the LORD and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
verses.comment: David honors even his former enemy Saul by mourning him.

verses.text: David said to the young man who told him, 'Where are you from?' He answered, 'I am the son of a foreigner, an Amalekite.'
verses.comment: The Amalekite reveals he is resident among Israel as a foreigner.

verses.text: David said to him, 'How were you not afraid to put out your hand to destroy the LORD’s anointed?'
verses.comment: To strike God’s anointed king was a grave sin in David's view.

verses.text: Then David called one of the young men and said, 'Go near and strike him down.' So he struck him, and he died.
verses.comment: David executes judgment according to the man's own testimony.

verses.text: David said to him, 'Your blood be on your own head, for your own mouth has testified against you, saying, “I have killed the LORD’s anointed.”'
verses.comment: David holds the man responsible for what he claims he has done.

verses.text: Then David lamented over Saul and over Jonathan his son
verses.comment: Sets the stage for the well-known lamentation or dirge.

verses.text: and he commanded that the people of Judah be taught the Song of the Bow; behold, it is written in the Book of Jashar:
verses.comment: The Book of Jashar is a lost ancient book of poems or songs.

verses.text: 'Your glory, O Israel, is slain on your high places! How the mighty have fallen!'
verses.comment: 'Your glory' refers to Saul and Jonathan.

verses.text: 'Do not tell it in Gath, do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised exult.'
verses.comment: Gath and Ashkelon are city-states of the Philistines, enemies of Israel.

verses.text: 'Mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew or rain upon you, nor fields of offerings! For there the shield of the mighty was defiled, the shield of Saul, not anointed with oil.'
verses.comment: David curses the place of Saul’s death; 'anointed with oil' refers to both the king and possibly the shield's preparation.

verses.text: 'From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan did not turn back, nor the sword of Saul return empty.'
verses.comment: Jonathan and Saul are depicted as valiant until death.

verses.text: 'Saul and Jonathan, beloved and lovely! In life and in death they were not divided; they were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.'
verses.comment: 'Not divided' refers to their bond and partnership even to death.

verses.text: 'Daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you luxuriously in scarlet, who put ornaments of gold on your apparel.'
verses.comment: Saul is praised for the prosperity brought to Israel’s women.

verses.text: 'How the mighty have fallen in the midst of the battle! Jonathan lies slain on your high places.'
verses.comment: Refrain repeated from verse 19; Jonathan’s death is focused personally.

verses.text: 'I am distressed for you, my brother Jonathan; you were very dear to me; your love for me was wonderful, more than the love of women.'
verses.comment: Describes the deep, covenantal friendship between David and Jonathan, not romantic.

verses.text: 'How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war have perished!'
verses.comment: Concludes the Song of the Bow with a lament for Israel’s heroes.
